bioghist.p: In 1982, the Center for the History of Chemistry (CHOC) was launched as a pilot project of the University of Pennsylvania and the American Chemical Society (ACS). In 1987 CHOC was incorporated as a not-for-profit organization, now named the National Foundation for the History of Chemistry, by joint action of the ACS and AIChE, the Center's third sponsor. In 1992 the Chemical Heritage Foundation (CHF) assumed its present name to better reflect the interdisciplinary nature of the sciences and industries it serves and the widening public scope of its activities.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the Chemical Heritage Foundation's research files on chemical corporations and industries, professional organizations and associations, and individual chemists. Records include: annual reports, printed histories, industry directories, and product listings and brochures from chemical manufacturing and research companies (1953-1992); interviews, biographical sketches, articles, and encyclopedia entries on notable chemists; and printed brochures and annual reports from associations and societies of professional chemists. The collection contains research materials from book projects on Samuel Natelson, John Dee, Robert Burns Woodward, and Arnold Beckman. These materials include: correspondence; photocopies of articles and works by the subjects; bound volumes of Natelson's publications; transcripts and audiotapes of interviews with Beckman; and photocopies of Dee's diaries. This collection also includes a small selection of documents relating to the Chemical Heritage Foundation's 1997-1999 board meetings and the Othmer Gold Medal.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
